Posts.Content: Jul 3, 2012 10:30PM Moiralf wrote: Hi Bkala, I am not posting this to make you more afraid but it is my experiences and I wouldn't want this to happen to anyone else. I had a noticable lump in my right breast and I had a mammogram. I was told "no problem" all good. At the time I hesitated and thought how could that be? But I trusted the docotors and the hospital and went on with my life. A year later the lump was still there, not really bigger but not smaller either. At a doc appt I mentioned it again and the doc sent me for mammo and ultrasound. This time it was immediately dx as cancer and I ended up with stage 4. I will never know if this would have happened anyway but i kick myself everyday for not pushing harder at the time for better answers.I didn't know I should have had an ultrasound as well. I didn't want to be a nuisance and thought they knew better than me and so I stayed quiet and went home. I don't blame anyone, no-one did it on purpose and it doesn't dominate my thoughts BUT I wish I had pushed harder. Please demand(nicely) to have whatever it takes to do everything to get a definite answer. Mammos can make mistakes, more often than we realise.  Remember most lumps are benign and again I don't want to panic you. Just encourage you to stand up hard for yourself. It is your health and life that is on the line.  I wish you all the best and look after yourself. Moira

Posts.Content: Nov 28, 2013 02:15PM Moiralf wrote: I love that attitude aaoaao. I don't think it's denial, it's a choice for the day. One you can make mentally without denying the reality. Cancer is not one of them so it doesn't belong in this day. No matter how much it wants to take over every last inch of mind and body. They will take care of themselves in their own time.Today open your eyes, ears, heart and arms and pull in and absorb the love and happiness that floats around us but can be hard to focus on with cancer throwing it's screaming paddy in the background. So even though we don't do thanksgiving in NZ I'm going to follow my own advice and have a thankgiving and acknowledging day. It feels good. Peace and blessings to you all. Moira

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2013 01:43PM Moiralf wrote: The one I find the most difficult to respond to is The Inspirational woman tag. How on earth did I deserve that. "The strongest woman I know" from my niece. No. I'm not, I wasn't before cancer and I'm certainly not after it. I'm just a normal woman living a reasonably normal life at the moment. None of them see me at home before an onc appt and how hard it is to get me into his office and only my DH sees me cry and struggle with the fear. The"living for ever" is a balant lie, we all die, including the speaker. For some reason, facing the reality of life and death is very difficult for some people.  Living is wonderful and a blessing but dieing is a natural part of life too. Not all of us will life to be old. Old is not all that much fun for them either sometimes. Mainly I just brush it off and leave people to themselves. They are trying to be helpful and don't know how else to say something to your face. Before all this, not sure I would have been too much different. Would like to think I was but no-one really thinks about what they say in some situations. Hate the fighting thing though. Totally agree with everyone on that. Load of BS and quite disempowering. Hate the pink thing too and the commercials on early detection. I had the damn mammo and got a misread. So much for them being the answer to it all. I think "postive" to get the most out of everyday and live with laughter and appreciation and to make happy memories for my family. I want to remember my life as being lived with joy and love as I head out the door. No wasted time and no regrets. Doesn't mean I don't live a full range of emotions to do it. Just I work hard on keeping the balance tipped to the happy side, but boy those scales wobble a lot sometimes. Moira

Posts.Content: Feb 19, 2013 05:36AM Moiralf wrote: Judy, I do know what you mean about not being able to let your DH know how much it upsets you. I do tell mine a lot of what I am feeling but I know it makes him sad when he thinks about it by himself. I do keep some of it back and try not to talk about it too much. Just now and then. One daughter can't cope at all and hates to hear if I'm upset. The other one is able to listen to me but I don't put too much on her either. She is 23 and I would prefer her to remember me as a happy, fun person, not a sad crying one. I found that going to a counsellor was my best outlet for the worst of my fears. Then I could talk about anything and it didn't hurt anyone but I could release the most deepest fears and then move on and find some peace for a while. I did that for the first 6 months or so and again when I had progression. Haven't been for a while and have moved since then so will have the problem of finding a new counsellor. I could rant and rave and cry and she would acknowledge my fears and somehow I would get a handle on them in my mind. My DH went to the same centre but had a male counsellor. He too found it helpful and he is not a talking kind of guy.  I never asked what they talked about but he found the same release and acceptance I did, I think. Moira

I've been doing this for 5 years and generally I have always felt the "why not me" thread of thought but it wouldn't be normal if every now and then, the bugger why should it have got this far and why can't I be stage something else. That's assuming I had to get stupid cancer in the first place. Makes me feel a bit small and mean but it is just a thought and it passes. If you sat around thinking it all day everyday it might mess with your head but an occasional wishful thought is perfectly normal. In my family my brother died of melanoma cancer at 45 in 2002, i got bc at 44 in 2007 and my elderly mum got stage 1 bc in 2010. So I sort of think, I have all these in my head." Glad to not be my brother"(that's mean), "sucks to be me but I'm living ok", and "how come my elderly mum got a fixable type of bc." But they are passing thoughts, then I come back to it all being it is what it is. Such is life. It shows what are good person you are that you have even noticed that it might not be ok to think bad thoughts. It's entirely natural. We think it's ok to wish we had been the one to win the lottery and all those millions so why not the not so happy stuff. It's like  a wistful sadness of what should have been. Then it passes and on we go looking for the good and blessings we have in each day. Pollyanna on. can't be pollyanna everyday, would end up killing someone with pent up annoyance and rage.lol Moira

Posts.Content: Jan 17, 2013 10:09PM Moiralf wrote: What a nice idea to introduce ourselves again. My name is Moira and I live in New Zealand. Recently shifted from the North Island to the South Island. They were very creative with the island naming when the Europeans settled here!! I am 50 now and just had a party to celebrate. Way keener to celebrate life's achievements than before BC. I have been married to a wonderfully imperfect man for 28 years and have 2 grown daughters. Neither married and no grandchildren. They are 23 and 27 so there should be GBs but no, modern women are too busy! I was dx from the get-go with stage4. Had a mamo the year before that should have shown the lump I could feel but gave me an all clear instead. That was Nov 2007. Scans after mast shown 1 met to spine. Had rads. Took Tamox for 2 1/2 years before it failed and then megace which did nothing and got mets in both hips and sprinkles up my spine. Had rads and Xeloda and got to NED in early 2011. Had a complete break from treatment for 6 months until TMs rose higher again and onto femara for the last year and a bit.  I've been very lucky that with all the treatments so far I have had few side effects. Really hoping that continues with all future ones. Not going to worry about that yet. I am an early childhood teacher and love the under 5 age group. Feel very passionate about the way the early years experience affects children though until adulthood. Not working right now as the shift south meant I had to leave my job and finding it a time to reflect and decide if I want to do something else. Plus it harder to find a job down here, people seem to love their jobs and don't shift, how rude, I need higher unemployment for me. Still thinking that the right job will come along when it is suppose to. Patience in waiting for anything is not my forte. Scans and doc appt require pills to see me though. Like now when I am due to see onc in early Feb, and he is going to ask for scans. Waiting for results is the worst thing. Oh almost forgot I have 4 cats. No dogs, we had to put our little foxy to sleep before our move, she was just too old and sick to have managed it. We had put it off too long anyway but I felt like we had done it just cos of the move. The cats should only be 2 but we rescued a couple before we shifted and couldn't leave them behind. Now I have a "gang" of cats. The support and unity this board gives women from all over the world is something I treasure. I would never have been able to find this understanding without the internet. Day or night you know someone is there. Moira

Posts.Content: Apr 22, 2012 01:26AM Moiralf wrote: Hi, I understand exactly how you feel. I'm 4 1/2 years out from stage 4 diagnosis from get go. Over that time I have been on Tamoxifen, xeloda and now femara. Each one has done great things for me when I have needed them. In that time I have been asymptomatic, very little physical symptoms at all. If it wasn't for TMs that do reflect something happening I would never have known about any of it. And again I have almost no SEs from any of the treatments. Great health really. I did have some pain in my hip when mets came there but only for a month or so and then xeloda squashed those. I feel so lucky but so guilty. It makes it hard to post because I don't want anyone to think I'm boasting about any of it. I haven''t done anything much to make it that way. It just is how it is happening for me. I cringe sometimes here and want to put my hand up and say Me too but don't want anyone to think, what does she know?  I mourn for those who haven't had what I've had but it is life and I didn't chose this but I'm not wasting it either. This is my life and God wants me to live it to the full I'm sure. I think of it as a way of honouring those that would have loved to have been here. My brother died of cancer at 45 after only a short battle. I know he would be pleased for me and be cheering me on.  I will not let cancer take my life from me in any way. I have a tattoo on my lower forearm that reads " Whilst we live, let us live" I have the number of years since the start of this worked around the words. On my anniversary each year I cross out the last number and add the new one. 5 is my new lucky number. I'm proud of that and will take those numbers to the grave. My onc jokes I might run out of room going up my arm. I told him that I could live with that.  Guilt is negative and gives nothing, just like fear. Look for positives like happiness, pleasure, laughter, hugs smiles kisses. Feels better when you do that. Moira

Posts.Content: Feb 2, 2012 10:35PM Moiralf wrote: Hi there, Wow you do sound so upset and you do have a right to be so. The CA15-3 and 27-29 measure proteins released by cancer cells. Not all docs use them as they are not very reliable and do not neccessary measure cancer growth. In saying that, my onc does use the CA15-3 test. The normal score would be under 35. That would sort of say no cancer. From the get go I was 45 on the CA15-3. That was 4 years ago and I was stage 4 from the start. My markers do show "trends" for me. My onc uses them to see if I need scans to check. A couple of years ago my markers started trending up and I will say well above your mum's numbers. I went for scans three times, every three months and the first 2 scans showed nothing. Clear scans.  The third one showed a small growth in my hip bones. I was at 1400 by then. That took 9 months of tumour markers doubling and rising rapidly.  Had rads to the area and went onto Xeloda. 8 cycles of that(24 weeks) I was back to 25. So you can imagine how happy I was with that. Now after 6 months of no treatment my markers rose to 100 and my onc put me on Femara. Each months markers have doubled and now stand at 400. Hoping that it is just femara taking a while to kick in. Just had my bloods done and I will visit my onc next Wed to get results. He has said that if it is still rising he would like scans to check things out. Scans are the important tool to see what is happening. The tumour markers are an indicatior for some people.  Most definitely not everyone. The important thing to realise is that if your mum has never had one done before thay have no base number for her. 70 might be fine for her. The scans are the answer for seeing what is happening. That is what I most want to stress. Yes, the waiting and the stress is hell and hard on everyone but it is just one of the neccessary evils we have to go though. Lots of women take some sort of anti-anxiety pill to help take the worst of the stress. Worrying for your mum is normal and it is lovely that you care but things might not be too bad. Hold onto that for now. She has had some wonderful time between each occurance and at the moment  that is still true. Circle the wagons, do what you can to remain calm and get the scans now to know what if anything you need to start dealing with. By the way, yes you are right infections can make your markers rise. Trust in the Lord and let Him walk with you as you go though the next few weeks. Hope it goes well for you and your Mum. I will be thinking of you. Moira

Still I will continue with lymp node drainage and MLD massage plus seeing the LEist to do her thing once a week. No idea about what I am going to do about a sleeve. I would like to try a lymphadiva sleeve but just not sure about what I should get.  Grrr. moira

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2014 04:06PM Moiralf wrote: Life does not stop does it? We should get a pass on all other trauma in our life's. Two weeks ago I went down to visit my 86 year old mother about an hours drive away. She wasn't at home and when I rang my brother and sister who live in the same town I got no reply. Funny I thought where could everyone be. Thought I would drive down through the little town and check if they were shopping. Then I spotted my brothers van outside the hospital. Quick u-turn and WTH moment. My mum had just been rushed to hospital after my sister found her collapsed in her garden. I had just missed the ambulance when I stopped in. Luckily it was heat exhaustion from hours spend gardening in warm weather and a  slight heart turn as well. Seriously  I told her I was the only one in the family allowed to have any health issues and she had to stop trying to steal my thunder and wait her turn. It made her laugh but ye gods it scared me. She is  a hardy old woman but still 86 nearly 87 is getting up there. I went home shaking a bit too and thinking about the future, Chris. Crying is good for the soul and we can both give thanks to whoever we please that it was not more serious. Guess they have lots of instructions what to look for over the next few days. Concussion is a sneaky beast. Moira

You know your dad was doing his manly best with us emotional women. Poor men are so often left with no idea why we need to cry but they do their best. Cry, curse and kick things if you need to  and then big deep breathes and then "Screw you cancer I'm back and you won't beat me". For me, if I can get a bit of anger at cancer trying to steal my life then I can get back up on my wobbly feet again and look forward. But I do have to have that wobble and I have never figured out a way to get past it. Not sure there is one. But you do learn you can get back up again. Moira

Posts.Title: Here I am, 6 years on. Moiralf aic

Posts.Content: Moiralf wrote: Hi everyone, I don't usually acknowledge each year of cancerversary but I remember crying my eyes out 6 years ago and believing I would be dead by now. So today it has been 6 years since dx. I do "celebrate" it cos I know how fortunate I am to still be here and doing pretty well. Plus new women who come here need to know that life is not over with the stage 4 dx. It has made me more aware of what I truly value in my life and I live with way more awareness of the preciousness of each day. I laugh more, have crazy fun and forget I'm suppose to be 50 and middle aged. I spend more time with my family, I take time to connect with friends and if I want to do something I do it. No putting it off or say Maybe later or I don't deserve that. I work less but still teach cos I love it and it makes me feel young but it done on my terms. So whatever the future holds I don't know. It is not for me to know. My business is living today and today I spent it with my dh and had lots of fun, just being together. I thank God that he walks with me on this journey and when I stumble He gives me strength to dust myself off and get my feet under me and move forward again. And a very big thank you to the many women I have met on these boards and the wonderful support and knowledge they have so generously given. Moira Moiralf Dx 11/16/2007, IDC, 3cm, Stage IV, 9/13 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2012 10:58PM Moiralf wrote: Hi Linette, My onc has always used TMs for me and over time they have shown to be a way of showing change. I was dx stage 4 nearly 5 years ago and my CA15-3 was around 45, had one bone met in spine. Was treated with radiation and tamoxifen. About 18 months later my markers started to rise and onc scanned, showed nothing. Three months later TMs higher again around 400 this time, scanned again, still clear. I think he waited for another three months and markers were 900 and scanned and I think this is when they found a small met in my hip. Had radiation  again and then megace which didn't work and TMs went to 1400, another met in other hip. Had Xeloda and with 8 cycles had TMs of 25. Since then I have had a break of all treatment until my markers headed up again after about 9 months and then I went on Femara and again at the beginning my markers were 1000ish,think I had a scan and had small spine mets, onc not that concerned, now back to 675 and dropping. No problem with my spine and I feel no pain. So from my experience only, scanning is great but in many cases it cannot pick up mets until they are a certain size. My onc also said they can't tell if the protein that is measured is a lot coming from a few cells  or small amounts coming from many. Not all of which will grow to anything. That sounds confusing but it sort of makes sense. The anxiety of going for scans and waiting for results was difficult for me and now I would wait until my markers showed up really high. That is me, that is what I have learned is true for me. That is not the same for everyone. My onc was surprised that nothing showed up when I was around 400 but it didn't. And if I had any noticable symptoms that were new for me I would be getting scans. Normal for CA 15-3 is under 35 so 44 is still very close and it sounds like they are rising incredibly slowly, mine sort of doubled each time so you can see the difference.  You could scan just for peace if mind and to feel like you are being proactive but the change to your treatment will be the same no matter when it happens, small or big doesn't make that much difference. One of the weird things about this is how onc say that to us. Getting mets early or a little later is not the problem, the way we each response to treatment is what matters.  Not sure if that helps but it is how it was for me. Your onc is watching closely and if you feel any symptoms that is also something he will want to know. He is right, 44 is still very low, but it is fair enough to be concerned. Moira

Posts.Content: Dec 3, 2012 09:22PM Moiralf wrote: Some people just don't get it. They just think of informing others and not the effect it might have on  an individual. One of the hard things about stage 4 is comparing yourself to everyone else with stage4. It's very hard to keep prospective and realise that each case is very individual. The thoughts go though your head, "That's me" "When will it be my turn" "If it can happen so fast to her it could do that to me" Panic is hard to describe in this situation but I have been there myself a number of times. I guess it some hard reality check that, yes this could be me and it's not just a possibility but at some point the reality. I'm thinking that for me it was a bit of time and the reassurance that everyone is different. Maybe spending bit of time with your mum and letting her talk about how that impacted on her and then very gently try to help her see that she is not exactly the same and right now she is still ok. It is not easy for us to get our head in the right space sometimes, especially when we see the end result staring us in the face. Denial is part of coping and death removes that barrier for a while. Maybe talking about caring for your father in the future and your mum knowing plans are being discussed and taken seriously will help her to relax and know she has some control back and her mind will settle. I would ask that you treat this seriously and with respect. I would have found it incredibly difficult if when it happened to me my loved ones brushed it aside and minimized how much it affected me. Some people don't want to talk about it and use the terms; Your fine, get over it and it won't happen to you. To me that would have been to disregard the very real feelings of dread and fear I was having at that time. Give her reassurance and listen to her and be gentle. Time will probably help to calm her. I'm sure you have done those things and I don't mean to imply you have not taken it seriously. You wouldn't be here asking if you didn't care very much for how this is effecting her. Just letting you know how it is for me and how I would want it treated. Hope your mum feels better soon. There is a very real grieving that we do for our future loss. Moira

Posts.Content: Oct 13, 2012 11:41PM Moiralf wrote: I'm with the others. I eat a balanced diet and enjoy fruit and vegies. I also enjoy sweet things now and then. Being happy and enjoying any type of food is going to make you feel better and enjoying each day is what life is all about. There is no magic bullet to stop cancer. Had a couple of progressions and currently on femara. Doing fine. I think you are trying really hard to do everything "right" and I don't think there is any such thing. Just life in all it's glory. Posts.Content: Jul 23, 2013 07:15PM Moiralf wrote: Yip, everyone one of us has in some way had to deal with anxiety and fear. How we do that is different for each person but there is much to live for, even with a stage 4 dx. I was dx wit bone mets nearly 6 years ago. I'm still going strong and no-one would ever know if I chose not to tell them. Imagine if I had not managed to overcome that shock and fear? I would still be alive but all that time would have been wasted and given over to fear. And believe me there was a great deal of shock and fear. I was devastated but I had to learn to fight through that and find someway to be happy again.  I refuse to allow cancer to take any more from me that it absolutely has to. If your wife has not already seen a doctor for her fears I would encourage her to do so. She may need anti-depressants to lift her mood and allow her to focus on moving forward. There is no shame in admitting we need help and many here take anti-depressants plus anti-anxiety meds to help us cope.  Counselling with a skilled therapist who knows how to deal with cancer clients is also very beneficial. It can be a place to share all her fears in a safe place and in doing that come to terms with how to get the most out of her life. It took me a good 6 months of counselling to feel I had reached a place where I could understand myself and the cancer. I still go back when things change and I need help to readjust. It may help her understand why she is avoiding certain foods. It may be one way she feels she can control things when so much else is out of control. None of what she has gone though and is still going though is easy, in fact it is damn hard work. She has worked hard to get herself mobile again and then the rug has been pulled out from underneath her. Make sure she knows what courage it took for that hard work and how together you will get through this too. She does not need to fear so much and there are things that can be done to help but she needs to step forward and decide she will fight for each day to be a blessing and not let the cancer steal that day. Be her loving support, remind her about those grandchildren. She does not have to fear but she will need help, she is not alone. Let her see this, remind her there are women here who do understand. There are many years let to be lived.  Thank you too for being the support you are to her. It is very hard on our families and our dear husbands want so much to make it all better when it can't be done. Take care of yourself and together you can move through this. Moira

Posts.Content: Feb 5, 2013 06:29PM Moiralf wrote: Can I add a bit from overseas,  In New Zealand rubbers are for removing pencil marks, what you guys call erasers, I think. That can be awkward for people who don't know. But, yes everyone knows they are condoms these days. So maybe more people are using the eraser term. We call galoshes, gumboots. No idea where that comes from but we all wear gumboots in the mud and outdoors. I had no idea what a hoogie or sub was, we don't have them. We favour English terms more than american ones and we don't have the influence of Yiddesh or european words. Here we add Maori words and everything ends in eh? if your from the north island but not in the south island. Seriously we are only two small islands yet there are difference with just that. One thing recently was the term "stick of butter". What is a stick and how much is it? Our butter is meaured in grams and you buy it in 500gram blocks. what about dresses or frocks? Here frocks is very old fashioned word but I wonder about other places. Moira
Posts.Title: OT - Regional Ways of Speaking redwolf8812 HLB

Posts.Content: Aug 24, 2012 01:24AM Moiralf wrote: Hi There, I've had bone mets for 5 years. Tamoxifen took care of the spinal ones for 2 1/2 years. Then mets in spine and hips, xeloda worked to get me to normal TMs. Then late 2011, rising TMs, scan,  onc told me things were stable but I had mets in spine, hips and ribs. He wasn't too worried and put me on Femara. Haven't had a scan since but TMs are coming down nicely which for me means it is working. Will scan in Nov to check if we are on the right track.  Only had pain once when I had pain in right hip from mets. They don't always cause pain. If you hadn't had the scans you wouldn't have known. My onc tells me I'm asymtomatic. No real signs things are happening. Lucky me, I won't even be sick it it wasn't for scans and blood tests. Well, I would be but I wouldn't know. By the time I did feel it the chances are it could be too late. So,while I curse the tests for smacking me with reality, they are also saving me. Still many treatments yet for you and the amount of mets are not as important as how you respond to any treatment.  I'm with the others who says enjoy your holiday and do everything you can to relax. Moira

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2013 03:09AM Moiralf wrote: Oh, you are indeed having a very hard time. What a fighter your mum has been and sounds like she will continue to be. No-one can say what is the best choice for her or what her response will be to another chemo. Being generous to your onc I would think he is giving you all the options. That can be very confusing and bewildering. There is no way to tell the future so you must weight the options and decide what is best for your mum as events happen. Her body is still healthy and that is great and it sounds like it is still in her bones so that is another plus.  Has she used any of the other hormonals other than arimdex? Is that not being suggested after rads? I know that the hospital is one of the best so you know you are getting good advice. I have heard that rads can make quite a difference to the pain of masses that block the spine. I had it to mets in my hips and it did make the pain go away, it can continue to work for a while afterwards so the end of rads is not necessarily the end of the benefits. This is a very difficult time for you all and it does take a little time to get your feet under you again and take a deep breath and look at what is next. Keep asking questions and then move forward and look after each other. Your mum has battled back once already so she sounds like she will have a good chance of giving this new one a chance to work on the mets. I am sure others will come along soon and have some more info on rads and on using gemzar. Hope it is a good one for her and the SEs are gentle on her. Moira

Posts.Content: Apr 8, 2013 03:22PM Moiralf wrote: Can you get a second opinion? My lump was large enough to feel but didn't show up on mammo. It didn't hurt at all but it was there and a year later another mammo and this time ultrasound found it and it was cancer. BUT, it took a biopsy to confirm it and I would suggest if you could get that done. I am not a medical person so this is only a laywomans thoughts. I regret I did not push to have my lump double checked the year earlier. I didn't know I should have had an ultrasound and my doc didn't bother. It is likely to still not be cancer but for some reason  you are having pain and that tells you that something is not behaving as it should. Advocate for yourself. Professional med people can still get it wrong or not be thorough enough. This is your body and you need to be assertive in looking after it.  Even if it is for your own piece of mind and it is not serious. Better safe than sorry as the old  sage advice goes. You can't go back and change things after it has happened.   Can you go back and ask for the next check? Or another doc? Mammos and ultrasounds are good but not without mistakes so that needle or core biopsy is the final answer. 10 years is much too long to wait. It's not their bodies giving pain and lumps, it's yours. Jump up and down. ask pretty please, beg but get peace of mind with a more definite test. Don't let them fob you off. Best of luck and I truly hope it is not too serious. Moira

Posts.Content: Jun 13, 2013 12:00AM Moiralf wrote: I had pain from bone mets in 2010 and needed two walking sticks to get around. I got rads on both hips and that helped with the pain but still I was on three different types of pain meds to deal with everything. Plus something to take for break through pain if the regular meds needed a top up. You should be able to get something to deal with pain. Onc don't always know about pain and a pain specialist or palliative care are much better and knowledgeable. Palliative care is not about end-time treatment but how to deal with the chronic aspects of cancer. After about 6 months I dropped meds down slowly and now only take pain meds when needed. But boy will I be jumping up and down if and when the pain comes back. Please get something that works to deal with pain. Stress is bad enough but pain drains everything out of you and mentally is so difficult. It's hard to be upbeat and positive if you are hurting. It's not fair and you deserve to be able to live in relative comfort. Hoping you get something soon and the scans are ok. I have had three progressions in bone mets and now waiting for scans to check rising TMs. But I have been doing this for over 5 years and it still scares the begeebees out of me and I worry about what treatment is next. But there are lots of options so I hold onto that. Let us know how you get on, you are not alone. Moira

Posts.Content: Nov 18, 2011 11:34PM Moiralf wrote: Hi Amy, On the 16th Nov 2007 I was diagnosed with right breast tumour and later in Jan I was finally staged 4 with a spinal met. Went on Tamoxifen and had rads to the area. Great for 2 1/2 years and then had tumours in both hips. More rads and then onto Xeloda. After 8 cycles of treatment I was in complete remission. That was in may and I am now having no treatment and going great again. I will move onto the hormonals sooner or later as I am now showing post menopausal blood markers. So, I have just "celebrated" 4 years as a stage 4.  I work full time, raise my family and love life. It has not always been easy at all. There is a lot of fear and anger, especially at the beginning but it does not have to dominate your life. Get your treatment plan, rally your support and look after yourself.  Be kind to yourself and don't let cancer rule you. Some days you can be strong and determined to fight and other days you go "Why Me?' Both are perfectly acceptable.  We are strong women but not super women. I think in some ways I have made better choices and made my life more fulfilling since the cancer than before. I now know I don't have time to worry about the small stuff and I do have time to laugh and make memories for those I love. I wish I didn't have this sucky disease but I do expect to be around for some time yet to plague my girls and love my husband. This board is a truly wonderful place to find info, ask questions and receive support. The amazing thing too is that it comes from all around the world, from women and men you would never met in any other way. Hope everything is coming together for you.  There is so much to take on all at once. Remember to breathe and take time to think things over. All the best.  Moira

Posts.Content: Jun 10, 2012 10:17AM Moiralf wrote: Hi Lynne, I think it is really hard for men in this situation. They are not great talkers like us. For them communication of feelings is like pulling teeth.  Where we live there is a pysh/oncology group of trained psychologists at the university. Though our local hospital we can have free counselling with these guys. It has been a life saver for me and although my husband didn't use it as much as I did, he did go and found it helpful.  Even now, 4 years later he will say I think I need to talk to them again. He hasn't so far, as like your husband he is very busy at work this year. I think his mental and emotional health  is more important than work but I leave it up to him to decide. But if I think he is struggling and needs to go I will put my foot down and insist.  Is there anything like that in your area? Sometimes talking to someone a step removed can be more helpful than someone with closer connections. He can say anything to them and not hurt their feelings or put them in a difficult position of not knowing what to say. Even though they can talk to us I know my husband doesn't like to express his fears to me as he doesn't want me to see that. Talking to a neutral person is one way he can let those fears out in a safe place. Depends to if your DH is a talker. Some men prefer to do physical stuff as a relief and for us women we have no idea why that works but men are wired different so that is my reasoning. Just spending time with  other male friends doing guy stuff might be the support he finds most useful. I think when we get so busy in our daily lives we forget to make time to relax and look after ourselves. Just as we need to care for our emotional and mental needs so do our partners. Your husband sounds like he is doing everything he can to help you and support his family. It is great that you realise he needs to be looked after too. Working together to look after each other will keep you strong as a team. You sound like you are looking out for each other and that is a wonderful thing. Keep the love strong and you can face anything together. Moira

Posts.Content: Mar 18, 2013 05:22PM Moiralf wrote: Hi There, Yep, it's  a confusing horrible time and the worst part is the waiting. I have no real advice as such but doing the biopsy could have set off your lymph nodes. They respond to activity in the body and can flare up after such things. If they stay up you might need to visit the doc sooner but hopefully they settle down in the next few days.  There is not too much you can do until you get those results and even then they may schedule more tests. It's part of the determining, is it, isn't it?? and it can take time. It's hard to wait though and some people use an anti-anixiety pill to get though so that could be an option for you. Try to do things that take your mind off it. Anything that works for you. Keeping busy, being with friends, running a marathon, scrubbing your house from top to bottom. It's easy to say but really hard to do but try. Don't let fear dominate. Until you have the facts in front of you, you don't have to do anything. Fear achieves nothing and robs you of any peace and normality you have.  Another thought, could you contact the doc's office and speak to the nurse and see if you can be seen sooner. The results are usually available before two weeks. Plus they might want to see you about the lymph nodes. All the best and really hope for good things. Moira

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2013 01:17AM Moiralf wrote: The above are good points. There are a few different tests so knowing which one you are using is important.They all measure the same thing but the numbers do look different. CA 15-3 have lower numbers than CA27-29. Normal for 15-3 is under 35. So as Spam said the rising trend is what the onc will watch for. Other things can influence a move too so it is a trend over time that is important. Scans are the actual test to follow TMs. My TMs are a good indicator but they had to rise to 1400 before my mets showed up on scans. Had scans every 3 months as they rose from 100 and doubling and more but until that big number each scan showed nothing. There, but not big enough to show on scans. Treatment shown the same response dropping again. hope that helps. Moira

Posts.Content: Apr 21, 2011 07:39AM Moiralf wrote:  Hello Cathy, No you are not be a baby.  You are going though something terrifying and trying to learn to cope in  a new way.  Be kind to yourself and remember to just breath, take it slow and gentle. You have time to learn about what is happening and how you can cope.  This is  great place to come and let some of those feelings and fears come out I was diagnosed stage 4 over three years ago and am still here and feeling fantastic.  In many ways I am in a better place now that I was before all this sh#t. It can be life changing in good ways as well as bad. But it can take a while to get to that way of thinking. You might like to think about some sort of counselling. That made an enormous difference to me. the person I went to see was experienced with cancer patients so know a lot about what I was  going though.  It took at lest 6 months of working with her and with myself before I could even think about the future.  I still know that the future is uncertain but that is true for everyone, no one knows what might be in front of them. the thing to try and keep in the fore front of your mind is that you are here today and today can be a wonderful day.  Then remember that some days are just bad bad,bad. Be gentle with yourself on those days and know that time will make things better. And come here, even if you don't want to post,just read. There are wonderful people here who give so much of their knowledge and wisdom to others. Draw strength from them and know that everyone has struggles but that it won't defeat them. Hope you are feeling better soon. In time things settle into something called "the new normal" Moira

Posts.Content: Oct 4, 2012 11:14PM Moiralf wrote: Generally, if TMs are accurate for your mum, it is a pattern over a period of time they will be looking forward. There can be many reasons why they can move around a little.  If your mum has not had many done yet then you need to wait and watch over the next few months to see if they keep rising or stay roughly around the same numbers. They can indicate a need to scan if they start rising in large jumps. Also, treatments need time to start working so TMs can rise for a few months before dropping Does depend which chemo your mum is on. Think it is ok to relax a little right now and play the "wait and see" game we all love so much. Sigh. Hard work to keep calm and carry on, I know. Moira

Your doc sounds like he is thinking ahead and saving you having to run around having scans and then more scans like your mum. Not very re-assuring I guess but so much better than dragging it out like you have already experienced. Take the same advice you got when this was your mum,one day at a time until you know what you are dealing with.  My mum got bc a couple of years after me. So we are a switch on your situation(but you don't even know yet, so hold on). It was not considered genetic as she was so old(82) when she got it that it was just luck of the draw. She got stage0 lobular and I got stage 4 ductal. I know which of us won that lottery. You know that it has been only been there to the touch for a couple of months and you did all the right things in being aware and then not over panicking and giving it time to resolve, then taking it to the doc. Hope your ultrasound and anything else show no problem but you have all the experience to know what to ask and to make sure they do the right tests to check. That is a positive out of your mum's problems. You won't let them muck you about and you will know exactly how far they need to go to make sure they get the correct and final answer. That gives you some power and control over this. Wish none of us needed to know but at lest knowledge is power. Fingers crossed for your scans and please let us know. Sometimes life sucks big ones. Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2012 02:11AM Moiralf wrote: Adding my experiences here too. I was stage 4 from soon after my mastectomy in 2007. One spinal met in the lower back. Got radiation to the vertebras around the met too. Went on Tamoxifen and this worked for me for 2 1/2 years. Then mets to right hip. More radiation and mets then found in left hip so spot weld to that one small met. Xeloda for 8 cycles and NED. I can return to using Xeloda again in the future so didn't stay on that as a maintaince treatment which is also possible. Back to a wait for over 9 months with no treatment until my markers moved up again. Now femara as I am now post menopausal. Should mention I was 45 when this started. 3 months on femara and markers dropping nicely. So hoping  for a long run on this. So have done 4 1/2 years and doing fine. Have been extremely lucky that I have very few side efforts from any of the drugs so far. I know how lucky I am with that. I use anti depressants to help keep my anxiety in the coping zone. I exercise because studies show that might help and I get counselling from a wonderful cancer experienced counsellor when I need it and I needed it a lot in the beginning where you are now. It's very scary and right now no-one can tell you what your journey will be but it is quite likely that you will indeed be there to see that graduation and so many other wonderful things before that.  Be aware of taking time to get your head around all this. It takes some time and cannot be hurried. Be kind to yourself and remember to breathe. Funny advise I know but sometimes that is all you  can do right in minute. This site has so much information that can keep you informed without scaring you sh****ss. Watch out for searching the internet. All the very best for your appts for the coming days and weeks. Moira

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2014 06:45PM Moiralf wrote: Excuse me Alyon, But does YOUR mum just have bone mets. I made that as a  sort of highlight cos to my way of thinking that is no where near a state to give up on.  Some drugs that have lower % response may still work. What if she was one of the ones who fell into the successful group. Lots of cancer drugs have quite lowish response rate if we but knew it but it's the best we have right now. My onc told me Taxol has only a 30 % response rate, sadly for me I hit the 70% boo hoo but now I'm trying FEC which has a 50% rate. Still not the 100% we would all like. And Taxol has been very successful for lots of women. It's just the way the cookie crumbles. Back to the ribs, Chrissy is right, rads are used more for pain. Apparently I have mets all up my spine, numerous ribs and both hips. I have had rads to both hips when at one point they became painful. Other that had I have no pain at all from any of the others. I don't even know which ribs and I don't care while they are not causing me any pain. When they do or a rib breaks or does something hellish wrong I will be screaming outside my onc door for getting it fixed now now now. Your onc seem a bit standoffish and pessimistic to me but that is only from hearing what you have told us. Do you have the option of seeking a second opinion. Not all treatments will result in worse SEs and check with the onc or pain specialist as to what can be done to alleviate her pain, or weakness. Seems from what you have said that she is willing to try.  Look for food she can eat and enjoy. Small and often worked for me with Taxol when it gave me a hard time. Onc reduced dose by 20% and most of that disappeared. Didn't work for me but them's the breaks. At least I didn't have to do 13 weeks of trying with nausea and heartburn. FEC which is highly emetic(vomit making) is completely controlled by my anti nausea meds. I thank them every time I take one. Don't give up. You sound strong both for you and your mum. Push a bit harder and insist they try new things for her. Or get them to tell you where else to go to get the answers you want. If it  is only in her bone yet as I think you said so, most of what she is going through is being caused by her treatments not her cancer or at least that is how I am reading it. Food wise, I found things like porridge, mashed potatoes, custard, yoghurt, dry crackers with a little cheese were more settling in my stomach. I called it my white diet. Some use shakes and powder drinks but what I had worked for me so I left them. I hated drinking all the time too and then I found I could easily take popsicles and that gave me fluid and a bit of sugar. I stuck with lemonade but fruit juice might be tasty too. I did still have to drink and I found rather than drinking just out of glass, a drinking straw actually made me drink more. Just the way my mind worked I guess but it helped me get enough fluid in. Long post but hope it helps in some ways. Moira

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2014 11:08AM Moiralf wrote: For everyone the words have different meaning in different situations and stages. There is no one right way. For me, personally, i don't mind journey. I thought of myself being on my life's journey before bc. It works for me. My journey involved my early life, my loving husband, the birth of my beautiful daughters, plus the heaps of other ups and downs it had. Then came bc, a really hilly bit to journey over and even it has it ups and downs and beautiful moments. This is my life, I don't know what  is ahead but right from the beginning of my whole journey the end destination is death. When,how and in what state I will be in has never been in my control. It will be what it will be. I don't think of anything being stolen from me, I never had it in the first place.It is only ever potential. That is how I chose to remain in exactly what I do have which is today. I chose to generate as much as possible any joy and happiness as  I can dredge to the surface. And believe me I am no Pollyanna. It sucks donkey balls but I am also greatly blessed, it seriously could be worse and I am daily grateful for what I do have. But the whole fighting/survivor thing gets me. At 6 years stage 4 can I be called a survivor. I consider each day one of survival for anyone, how can it be applying to only one small group. And what indeed have they survived.  Still won't survive life girls and boys, it gets us all so keep looking over your shoulder. Fighting to me is redundant in physically terms. Damn cancer does what it likes and takes me along for the ride. Treatments work or it doesn't. Again not a lot to do with me. Eat healthly, exercise gently, do alternatives, yes they are part of my wellness package but my body is in control and I ride along with it. My fight is mental and emotional. I can work hard to stay in the moment, to live blowing raspberries at cancer and seizing the day. To inhale the beauty of sea, sky and nature and be glad I live where I am and with the people I do. When my mood drops and bad results come in and i face the harsh reality of what is most likely staring at me. I work hard to remember it is not now, it might be one day sooner than I would like but what if it isn't. Minds play mean and horrible tricks of taking us to our nightmares. It's all a mind game. Thoughts are not real they are projections of possibilities.  That is my fight and it 's hard fought and sometimes I lose and cry and scream and it's not stinking fair. But such is life, it isn't designed to be fair. We don't always "win". And if my dh mentions in any sentence, death notice or church sermon Fighting, fought or warrior. I will find some way to come back and make him really sorry he didn't listen to me more closely. This is my long and personal view.  Moira

Posts.Content: Jan 2, 2013 09:56AM Moiralf wrote: Shelmel, This is a terrible time for you. Crying and cussing is normal and I would say healthy. I'm no doc and can't comment on the treatment but there must always be hope until proven otherwise. It is possible that you will respond well to your chemo and knock them back. Even aggressive tumours can respond to treatment. I do agree that right now you might need some extra help in the form of anti-anxiety or anti-depressants. This is a huge blow to cope with and there is nothing wrong with getting something to help ease that. Talking to a councillor might help too. The thoughts go around in your head until you can't even think anymore. Talking to someone who deals with this professionally can help to sort out the tangle and maybe clear some of the mess rolling around in your brain. When I was first dx I felt like there was someone screaming in my head all the time and it wouldn't stop. It was worse knowing it was me screaming silently in pain. Come here and talk or read, people will hear you and you are not alone. We do sort of understand as no-one else can. Very gentle hugs to you. Moira

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2012 03:39PM Moiralf wrote: Hi Canadagirl, It does sound more hopeful doesn't it? It's not obvious and that is good I think. I am one of those that the CT, MRI, Bone scan didn't show up the spot that was concerning as a met. All my scans were read by a number of docs, trying to get a definite answer. In fact, the bone scan showed a very clear picture of the vertebrae but the doc said it wasn't showing up enough as what they call a "hot spot" and they were pretty sure it wasn't cancer. I was so very happy that day. But in order to be sure he ordered a bone biopsy. That took a couple of weeks to do and get the results back. It was cancer from that so yes sometimes it takes that much but there is sort of list of tests they  use and most of the time they get the answers without having to run though the whole lot. It does take time and there is noting worse that expecting to get real answers and coming away with more questions. It just sucks but it is the way it is. Hold onto the fact that it is only those three small spots that are even concerning them. And even the fact that they can't tell from the other scans. It's NOT obvious so to me that would mean it is not big n nasty but small and quite likely not cancer. Hope you get the biopsy soon. It's quite easy to do but you need to make sure she gets good relaxants and anesthetic around the site. Can be achy a couple of days at the very most but nothing major. So sorry it is taking so long but look on it as a positive. Cancer is a sneaky beast but your out hunting and it won't get away. Moira

Posts.Content: Sep 4, 2013 05:58PM Moiralf wrote: The lack of control and our inability to find all the answers can drive you nuts with this. For every question you have there is any number of answers and none that can be the correct one. We live in a society that now expects to be able to solve problems, get the answers and be in control of ourselves. Cancer teaches us very quickly that we are often along for the ride and we have limited say in what the stupid little b**gers do. It's one hell of a life lesson. But there is huge amount of life still to be lived. Life becomes very precious and we can be more in our lives than before. Nothing is taken for granted and the people around us that care for us and love us are very important. I wish there were more answers to your questions but I don't have any so no help there.  You just have to walk the journey and deal with each part of it as it is revealed. Not easy at times and plain sucky at others but it is life in all it's glory so it is what it is. I don't want you to think it is all negative and hopeless, it most certainly is not and fear is your biggest enemy. Deal with what you know, not what might happen.  As someone said here before,This is a marathon not a sprint.  And yes, while your waiting, waiting, waiting, try to life today with joy and pleasure. Refuse to let cancer take today from you. All the best for your mum's scans. They are scary wait times.

Posts.Content: Feb 17, 2014 01:30AM Moiralf wrote: Ali I too had a lot of back pain and at  the time most of mine was nerve related(before cancer). Physio did help but I had a physio who had treated my back for years. I worked in early childhood and all the lifting and twisting was hard on my back after 20 years. So I had a lot of trust in her and she used exercises, similar to yoga to help ease my spine/vertebrae, nerves all back in line. For me that fixed me in the time before cancer. After my dx cancer was found in one of my bottom vertebrae but it wasn't painful and never has been. Go figure!! When the mets came in my hip in 2010, pain and more pain developing over about three months. I had rads and then I was sent to a pain specialist, not my GP and not my onc, they are not the people who know this stuff best. A bit worryingly the pain specialist is often based with hospice. Can be a bit freaky, but it is not hospice they just run alongside each other. So when you say you are taking strong pain meds, who prescribed them and what are they?  I ended up with three different types of pain meds. One for bones, one for nerves and one for muscles and general things. Then I was closely supported as too how I was doing and if they needed to increase levels, which they did a couple of times. When the pain was under control  they kept in touch to make sure I was ok. About 6ish months later I started reducing the amount I was taking and in the end I didn't need any of them. Like Chrissy said you do need more than an exray, in fact for my back I have never had an exray. I've had CT, MRI, bone scan and bone biopsy. It took all of those to finally get a definite dx of cancer cells. Before that they were sitting on the fence and unsure as each scan might have been or maybe not. Bone scan said No it wasn't cancer. Just to be sure they did a bone biopsy and guess what...... cancer cells!. So I know the benefit of being totally thorough  and am thankful to my onc for not stopping at the bone scan. Even if it is nerves in your vertebrae or your discs there should be some pain relief you can get while you explore if physio might be helpful. With the hormonals, which I have been on Tamox and femara, I didn't get joint pain but many women who do say they find gentle stretching and exercise actually reduces pain. Sounds wrong doesn't it. Swimming or aqua jogging is really good too. I do that when I'm not doing chemo. Sorry for the long post but I have been there, done that, so thought some ideas of what has worked for others might help. If you are in pain, don't take no for an answer and a doc's shrug is not ok either. There are many options but you have to find the right people who know their stuff and can prescribe and monitor you properly. I'm in New Zealand so some of my labelling of people might be different where you are but close enough I think. Push and keep pushing until you get what you need. Pain is not acceptable  unless every avenue has been exhausted. Moira.

Posts.Content: Oct 18, 2012 07:03AM Moiralf wrote: Hi There, I'm not sure I'm going to be reassuring exactly but I will tell you mine were found by Ct scan followed by MRI, bone scan and bone biosopy. So took a bit of finding. Had one met in my lower spine. BUT I had node involvement of 9 out of the 13 they took so you can see that it was much more likely that at some point they would find something. I had no pain for that met but some people do. A couple of years later when I got mets in my right hip, yes they hurt, a constant dragging pain. But they also found them in my left hip at the same time and no pain in that hip, go figure. I think, with my very limited knowledge, that with your dx it is pretty unlikely what you describe would be mets but scans would be the most conculsive way of finding them. Xrays are a good place to start so doc isn't wrong.  Anxiety is very normal at this time and as things settle down you will relax. One of the other things docs say is if the pain is still there or increasing after 3 weeks then look at it. Gives normal aches and pains a chance to settle and we can stop holding our breaths. Elbows are generally not a place mets go but ribs can be, usually would still hurt whether you touched them or not. Hope this helps, sort of rambling but that is what I have found with mine. Getting reassureance can help you know what is "normal" or not, so if nothing else helps push for the scans even if it is just once so you can see that everything is clear. All the best. Moira

Posts.Content: Dec 4, 2012 12:31PM Moiralf wrote: 1Athena1 Hi, I can tell you how my were but as you know everyone's are different. Mine started in my knee, with an ache that I thought was from the treadmill at the gym. I have had back pain before and my  original mets was to my L3. I didn't think this was mets but I didn't have any pain from my back mets either so I had nothing to judge it by..  We were going to Europe in Oct and this was Sept. On my visit to onc before I went he asked about why I was limping. Told him my knee hurt from the gym. We agreed between us that I would have it looked at when I got back. My TMs were rising so I think he knew there was a chance it was mets. The pain gradually left my knee and headed into my hip and over the month in Europe it got worse and I had to take painkillers most days in order to do all the walking up and down stairs. Europe has a lot of stairs by the way. Everything is either upstairs or in the basement of places. I did a lot of stretching and trying to move my hip joint as I had had back problems and sciatica for a long time. It didn't help and when I got back and they did a scan I had a tumour in my illiac joint. My pain if I can remember was constant and deep and didn't go away with normal painkillers. In an aside the interesting thing was that as I was having rads to the right hip I slipped off the rads table and landed badly on my left hip trying to protect my right. Immediate pain and trouble walking and two days later they did another scan and found 3 small spots in my left hip. No pain at all and who knows how long that might have taken to show up. The general rule is if pain has not changed or disappeared in 3-4 weeks and there is no clear reason for it then it is a good idea to get it checked out. Maybe if you have a physio you use you could get it looked at there first and see if they can improve things. If it's tumours that will make no difference but it might solve your problem if it's muscular. All the best with this. In the end you have to decide for yourself if the worry is worth waiting or you are better off knowing what is and isn't going on. Moira

Posts.Content: Jan 14, 2013 06:03PM Moiralf wrote: Hi Canadagirl, Your poor mum and you, the questions never stop do they. When you think you have a sort of understanding on it all, up pops something else. From my experience and what I have read here about others, your onc treatment is standard. Rads to kill the cancer on the spot and reduce pain and hormonals to continue treatment. They are considered the gentler option and do work very effectively. They tend to be a bit slower at reducing tumours but just as effective. Chemo is so much harsher and many onc keep them for when the hormonals stop working or if you have a huge jump in activity and they want a quick shut down of the tumours. Mine did that a couple of years ago when megace stopped working and I had more mets in spine, ribs and hips. Tiny ones but there. Did 6 cycles of xeloda,had complete response and went onto femara, which has continued to work for over a year now. Once a chemo has been used it often can not be re-used so onc keep them for later when hormonals have done all they can. That is a bit of a simplistic explanation but the general gist of it. Your mum plan is/was very similar to mine and it does work. Still, hoping for you guys that you don't need it. How long to they think you will have to wait for this result? Moira

Posts.Content: May 13, 2013 05:59PM Moiralf wrote: Hi Lynn, Damn and double damn. I was stage 4 from the get go and my mum was dx 3 years after me with stage 1. Funny old world. Stormynyte is right I think. You are asking very caring questions and it is obvious how much you want to help. The thing is your parents have a long established relationship and it works for them. How far do you go in pushing into that relationship "for their own good". Truly I don't know. You want to help and as a by stander you can see how things could work better but is it right to do? I have no answer to that but feel you need to consider their wishes and way of interacting together too. Your pop being at the appt may help.You might be able to slide questions in that you think he should hear the answers to.  Treatments are different for those in their older years. My mum was 81 when dx. It made me cry to think she would have to go through what I had gone. She had a mx and since she was stage 1 they decided no hormonal either. No rads either. We are in NZ and they believe in quality of life rather than quantity of life here so they are less aggressive in treating,and doing things they think will do little to prolong life and be too hard for older bodies to cope with. My mum is 86 now and doing fine with no recurrnace.  You have to weight up those two things very much when dealing with someone who is already in their 80s.Plus your mum wishes for treatment. What you want for her and what she wants for herself. I don't think there is any easy answer and these questions wil come up time and again as you all try to work your way through this. My mum is no hugger either but I just rang her and kept in touch(we didn't live nearby) If she wants to talk let her but she may be private about what she tells you. Plus if you push too hard will she stop telling you anything? She is an adult and can make those decisions  for herself even if you don't agree. This is tough and I can see how this could be very painful for the whole family. One thing to remember. This is her journey not yours. You have to respect that. Please come again and ask questions and air concerns. It is obvious you want the very best for your mum. Moira

I did have all my nodes removed when I had my mast but at the time they did not know it had spread to my spine. I did get lymphodema 18 months later so it can take a while to show up. As your DD already has the stage 4 dx I can't quite see why removing them now would be any help. Like shutting the stable door after the horse has bolted. That is my lay opinion anyway. Having lymphodema is not the worst thing but it is a pain in the a** and best avoided if at all possible. Moira P.S. A** is not arm by the way, although is it a pain in the arm.

Posts.Content: Aug 20, 2012 07:37AM Moiralf wrote: I was stage 4 from the get go, also with an misdx lump. Took another year to get it right and then  after a few more tests they finally found a single spinal met. Would have been stage 3 and treated as such if my onc hadn't decided that he wanted a bone biopsy done as well as the bone scan(that said not cancer). I was even more unusual because other than the lump in breast I had no symptoms. Still don't really show anything except in Tms rising. So I'm called asymptomatic as well as unusual. There are quite a few "get go stage 4" on this board but it is a big group covering many parts of the world. I'm just glad we have it because before the internet it would have been terrible and the feelings of isolation would have been so much worse. I have heard of cancer groups not feeling that stage 4 can met with other stages, we scare them I think. How do they think we feel being called the bogeyman of cancer or woman in our case. I was really fortunate that I had a group that did cover all stages of breast cancer, some were a few years out of early stage but they still needed that support too. We didn't really linger on stages but talked about all aspects of how cancer affected our lives. Only met for 6 months but it was fine while it lasted. I'm with coolbreeze and the others. Even a letter to the organizers pointing out how being excluded made you feel. It's not catching you know and some of those women might one day be in your position. Having some knowledge that it is not yet the end of the world might help. By the way, I'm nearly 5 years out and still doing well. I don't have "stage 4 cancer victim" stamped on my forehead and I fight anyone who trys to tell me I 'm not as normal as the next person. Pretty sure there isn't anything such thing as "normal" Moiralf

Posts.Content: May 17, 2013 10:48PM Moiralf wrote: Sounds connected to your expanders and lymn node surgery. Nerves etc can take a while to heal and sometimes you can get shooting pains from nerves firing randomly. Just the joys of the journey. Talk to your docs about it but it sounds connected to muscles rather than bone. It is really hard not to question everything your body does from now on but hopefully things settle down and you start recognising "normal" body reactions. I was also reading your question on TMs and was going to ask which test you onc uses. There is CA  27-29 and CA 15-3. They do the same thing but numbers range differently depending on which one is used. Your number sounds low to me and it also depends on what your numbers have been before. If this is your first time then you have no pattern to follow. TMs can be totally useless for some people and show patterns for others. But a single or even couple of tests are not sufficient to provide enough data. It is when they show a consistent rising or doubling pattern that oncs start to look for scans to see if things are changing. Rising or falling a few points is not enough to be too concerned about. It needs to be big jumps, other things including chemo can have an affect on them so many oncs don't even use them as they can be too scary and unreliable for patients. They are generally used more for when you already have mets cos they can show respond to treatment. Again they are often unreliable even then. Stupid things, but it is all part of the tricky nature of cancer. It's natural to have many questions and sometimes it is after the first round of treatments are finishing that you start to think about what if. You need to learn to "read" your body again and look forward without fear. That is tricky for many people and sort of hard to come to terms with when you are coming out the other side. Give your self time to settle down and heal body and mind. And be kind to yourself, no one has all the answers. Moira

Posts.Content: Nov 16, 2012 11:20PM Moiralf wrote: Hi Canadagirl, This is a great place to come and ask questions and also to just read others posts. It can give you lots of info that you may not even think to ask your onc. There is no cure once you are stage 4 but there are many treatments that can manage the cancer for long periods of time. You haven't given your mum's status and grade of cancer, but I'm guessing from the fact that she was on tamox and then femara that she is ER+ and Her2-. Otherwise I think she would have had hercepten as well. It is likely that the tamox and femara successfully held the cancer at bay or stopped it coming back for those 11 years. There are still other hormonals that work very well and many chemos that can knock the cancer back and then return to hormonals again.  So, it depends on what the what your mum's onc recommends for her treatment plan. I had stage4 from the get go with single bone met. That was 5 years ago yesterday and I'm living a normal life doing everything I did before. Have had ups and downs and a couple of changes in treatment but that is to be expected. When I was first diagnosed I had bone mets and I have had more in my hips a few years ago. I was given radiation to the area, this help with pain management and fried the little bu**ers, which felt good.  All the time I have felt fine and in the beginning my bone met in my spine never hurt at all. Only the ones in my hip did. I have had few side effects from the hormonals and even xeloda which is a chemo taken as a pill was fine. Some people have more reaction but your mum has already had tamox and femara so she is obviously use to them. Take a big deep breath and remember that this is a hard time until she gets onto her new treatment plan and things settle down. It does sound quite positive in that her general health is good and those pesky mets have not really given her a major problem yet. That pain was a good reason to find these now and get onto killing them stone dead, that's the way I like to see my pills working for me. You will get lots of good advise here and women who are so supportive and encouraging for both you and your mum. They are just awesome and so helpful. I agree with Racy, you can get copy of the report but remember that it does need to be read with a medical slant. But it does help to remind you about status of receptors etc. The lung nodule may or may not be cancer remember. It can be other things or just a funny reading of the scan. This is very doable for your mum and she has been doing this for 11 years. This is just a bump in the road as my breast care nurse use to tell me. Felt like a brick wall at the time but is does retreat to the bump in the road after a while. All the very best and do come back if and when you need to. Moira

Posts.Content: Dec 6, 2012 09:25PM Moiralf wrote: Canada girl  I have been watching and hoping things went well for you and your mum. Why can't onc just be straight forward and do the things we expect them to. So if I understand it right, they biopsied the other side from the big lump because nothing was found there. That is good news but if it was bone it might not show up in either CT scan or ultrasound. That is possible, and you need the bone biopsy to confirm no cancer cells. Still good news that it is looking more likely that it is not mets there. The onc may have some suspicions about the lymph that he wants a definite answer for and depending on that he may order more tests. What a long drawn out process this has been for you all. It is very tiring to build up to these tests and the still not get any answers. It's very hard on the nerves. So, it is still wait and see what the next visit tells you. I think it might be very useful to write down the questions you have and take them along. Then make sure you ask them all and get clear answers from the onc. Write the answers down so you can process them later. It is surprising how much we miss hearing and remembering. Or each person there hears it differently.Don't let the onc rush you and be happy with the fullness of his answers before moving on to the next one. Sometimes we feel like we have stupid and trivial questions and don't bother him with them but they are usually the ones that bug us the most. If your mum English is not good then even recording the meeting and being able to replay later might help her understand at her own pace. I know many women here record their meetings. Quicker and easier than making notes i think. Still in many ways it seems positive for a good result. Still playing the waiting game though. Moira

I was stage 4 from the get go. So in about 2 weeks it has been 6 years stage 4. In the beginning I cried cos if my lost future and then through counselling and my own beliefs I decided that I never had that "promised" future. The reality is that we only have today, who knows what my future might have had in different circumstances. There arn't any other realities, just the one we are living. I thought I would just get sicker and sicker and die. I could have lived with that predication and lived my life accordingly but I decided cancer wasn't taking my present from me. It might have my future, I can't control that but I do have a say in what I do today. I can live with cancer taking any pleasure and happiness out of the day or I can look around and believe that I have many blessings in my life and I am damn well going to enjoy them while I can. Cancer will not pollute and steal my today and I can't even beginning to predict what the future holds. As it is, I'm still doing very well, I've had progression but it has been beaten back a couple of times and right now I'm doing Taxol for liver mets. Hoping it working but who knows. I don't, but today is lovely and sunny, I'm not working today and I'm getting out and about. I'm no Pollyanna, this disease devastates me, but if there is any truth is the survivor/fighter talk it is in how we fight to live rather than allowing cancer to steal our lives long before we actually die. That is the true battle. I hate cancer, I rage at it and I refuse to let it steal my present, screw it, it's my life today and I'm fighting to live rather than waiting to die. Sorry this is so long but it is something I've been aware of as I come up on the 6 year mark. Moira

Posts.Content: Nov 19, 2012 03:51PM Moiralf wrote: Hi again Canadagirl, Yes, they do need to do more scans would be my answer, in the short version of what I would tell the doc. When I was diagnosed it was in one vertebrae on my spine. That was shown on the first CT scan. BUT, the docs said it looked suspicious for mets but not conclusive, it could have been other things as I had back problems before, so I was sent for an MRI, which shows a different way of seeing the bone and fluid etc around it. I'm not an expert on how they work or why doc order them I just know they do. The MRI again showed something but it was still not that clear to be definitely ruled as mets. So this time a bone scan, that showed what they call a "hot spot" again BUT they thought it was not cancer from the scan. Finally my onc sent me for a bone biopsy which did indeed find cancer cells. It was mets in the final run. So, you can see that one CT scan is not a definite test for mets. It is possible for breast cancer to come back even after all those years but it is also possible to get another different cancer.Your mum's onc does need to find out what is actually in those spots and a bone biopsy would be the only way to do that I think. Don't quote me on that, I'm no doctor but they can't tell from outside the bone what sort of cancer it is. Maybe on Thur your onc will discuss having the other scans done to check. Other wise ask, it is very normal to get a couple of tests done each time. Even now after 5 years I still get a CT scan and a Bone scan each time. They run in tandem for bone mets. One will show somethings and one will show others. Sometimes my CT scan will show stuff that actually should show up on the bone scan but isn't and then the other way around. I have no idea why. This whole journey is loopy at times and I just listen to what the whole result is.  Good luck with your appt but I certainly would be pushing hard for more concrete info and a biopsy to be sure. Moira

Posts.Content: May 17, 2013 09:06PM Moiralf wrote: Hi There, Hard not to panic isn't it.  You tell yourself it's fine and then you spend the next hour poking and prodding to see if you can tell where the pain is. No one can tell you what is causing the pain exactly but have you spoken to your doc?  My experience with bone mets it that they hurt all the time and don't go away. You say it feels like muscular pain and it is possible you are pulling a muscle at certain times and this is resulting in the pain coming and going. Have you tried an anti flam on it to see if that eases it when it is hurting. Sometimes a hot pack to see if that helps. If that provides relief then it is unlikely to be mets. Bone mets can feel like a very deep aching pain, not so much sharp and biting. But, everyone is different and so it is hard to tell. If in doubt, check it out. Plus you will be able to relax maybe a little. Try the usual things to help a pulled muscle and if it all continues see your doc. It is absolutely ok to freak out and worry about every pain but there are all the other usual culprits that caused pain before bc to consider too.  Hope it goes away or you get some relief. Moira

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2013 10:54PM Moiralf wrote: I agree with the others Renae, You will waste precious time trying to make sense of it all. There is no answer. It is what it is. No-one knows the why. If you take this to it end you could say Why were you born? Why do you look like you do? It is just part of life and living. From your other posts you are in a very hard place right now and that is what you need to try and focus on.  You will drive yourself into an even worse place if you don't get help and turn this around. It is not unusual to question the whole why thing but it is leaving you in a very bad place and I can tell how unhappy you are. Please look to see what there is near you in terms of counselling or get some anti-depressants to help. I think you said in one post that they made you dizzy but there are others to try that may not have that side effect. Do you have a church pastor you can talk to or can they help finding someone you can talk to. Even if you have tried this and it hasn't worked don't give up, try and find another one. When you feel as bad as you seem to be right now it is hard to find the energy to reach out one on one but you need to. If you can't, is there a family member who can be the one to make contact or find help and be there to support you. Being brutal and I apologise in advance if this unwelcome but you sound seriously depressed and you may not be able to get out of this without professional help. There is nothing wrong with saying that and making those on your medical team help support you. This is a terrible place to be and you don't deserve to be left to deal with it all yourself. I truly hope things get better for you and you find some joy in life again. Moira
