Posts.Content: Jul 13, 2013 07:07PM Moiralf wrote: One of the worst parts of sharing our lives with animals is that they just don't live as long as us. For children that is so hard to understand. The best parts of sharing our lives is the joy and pleasure and love they give us. So in the end we hope the joy helps us let them go. It's so hard for children but they do understand that they wouldn't want the dog to suffer and be in pain and they can remember all the great times they had with them. My children have often surprised me with their ability to accept that better that I can. Saying goodbye is very important and knowing that their pet had such fun in that last afternoon will be a happy memory. And in a while they can think that there are many animals that need loving homes and how wonderful it would be to give an unwanted dog a great home. Children get that really well too. Moira

Posts.Content: Oct 3, 2013 11:11PM Moiralf wrote: I want to chip in to add that I was dx stage 4 with one bone met to my L5 so quite similar to you but further down. That was in 2007. My treatment was rads to that vertebra and the ones on either side, piece of cake to do and had no Ses from that. Think it was 5 days one after the other. Then onto tamoxifen which held me NED for 2 1/2 years. Then progression in 2010 in both hips and onto xeloda for 8 cycles. Again NED at the end. I had some peeling of my hands and feet.  Tiny amount and in no way interfered with doing anything. A really good hand and foot cream helped enormously with healing. So it can be done like than without the Ixempra and be very effective. But like the others have said MD Anderson is one of the best. Maybe ask why they feel it is necessary. Or you could start out with one only and see if you get good results. Really hope it all works out for you. Moira PS In Nov it will be 6 years since my dx and I have lived a full and a new normal life. I was 45 at the time and thought my life was over. Totally not true but only by living day by day can that be learnt. It's not easy but it is doable to look forward and not let cancer dictate every area of your life.

Posts.Content: Jan 9, 2014 12:28AM Moiralf wrote: Hi Karen, My onc referred me to the palliative care team at my hospital for pain relief. I had pain in both hips from mets and while they were being treated with rads and chemo the pain was quite bad. As he said, palliative care manages pain better than medical oncs. They were great and very quickly got me on a good blend of meds that got the pain completely under control. They rang weekly to check with me and when I wanted to decrease dosage and come off they helped with that. That was 3 years ago and I would not hesitate to use them again.But it is funny how we associate "palliative" with "terminal" cos it is but in actual terms they do different things. But it does take a bit to move pass the word and know it is not any way an indication of getting closer to the end. Really hope they have something amazing to get the nausea under control. Moira

It was not painful, sat right at the top of my spine and I was sure it wasn't there before. My poor DH tried to calm me down and got on the net to search for anything it could be. I can only blame the panic he was feeling for his answer. All he said he could find was as we got older we got a fat neck. I BEG  YOUR PARDON. In the middle of a crisis you are telling me I've got a fat neck!!!. He should have known better after 28 years of marriage. My daughter made me take a chill pill and apart from obsessive checking I settled down. It hasn't changed at all and I will check with the onc on my next appt but Likely it is just the shape of my spine and neck and has been like that for a long time. Still lead to a complete panic attack. The smallest things can do it. Have you had a chance to call yet and get any answers. Then if they are not available and will ring back  when they can that can set you off as well. Deer in the headlights look. Moira

Posts.Content: Dec 16, 2012 02:14PM Moiralf wrote: I would agree with the others about contacting hospice now. It doesn't mean giving up, it means being in control in  a different way. When I had very bad pain from my hip mets my onc got me to contact hospice. I was horrified but as he said they dealt much better with pain management. He was right too. I had a regular person who contacted me quickly, dealt with me and how my pain was effecting me and prescribed better pain meds than my onc. She kept in contact with me by phone every week until I was pain free and after rads and more treatment my mets were dealt with. Then she put me on what they call List B, which means I was no longer in need of their immediate care but was on their radar should I need them again. Katbob has a very good point, at this time you are in control and the pressure is not so great. You can get to know them in a slightly more relaxed time and not under pressure when you are seriously not well. They are just part of your on-going treatment plan and you will have time to consider each step. They may have some of the answers to those questions that are stopping you sleeping. This is their area of specialty rather than the onc I think. Moira

Posts.Content: Dec 17, 2012 08:59PM Moiralf wrote: After Tamox failed for me and I got mets in my hips and spots up my spine my onc put me on Xeloda to slap the cancer back and get it under control. I did 8 cycles and my TMs 15-3 went from 1400 to 24. In the normal range and then he stopped me and let me go with nothing for 6 months until my markers again rose to 1100. Put me on femara and for the last year I have been going every 3 months and just doing TMs. Still 135 on Nov test but everyone is happy. Haven't had scans since last nov which was when they knew the spots were coming back. Femara and xeloda both work for me and at the moment femara is bringing things down slowly but surely. I know that I can return to xeloda at a later date and the longer between then and the next time will mean a better response. Each treatment has a certain life and I want to keep xeloda as a good backup with the likelihood of a good response for the future. I think if you talk to your onc he might agree to another cycle of  xeloda before going onto femara. And they usually do monitor closely to make sure things are working. It's a tough decision when you know what you are currently on is doing the job to trust that something untried will work. A leap of faith I suppose. Moira

Posts.Content: Moiralf wrote: Hello, I know there is a wonderful Femara thread but it is really long and I'm hoping for a quick answer. I had a great response to Xeloda and in May I was NED and had TMs CA 15-3 of 27. Stopped Xeloda. After a couple of months the TMs started rising again and in Dec I had CA15-3 of 400. So onto femara, it has only been just over a month and today my TMs were 900. My onc is suggesting I stay on femara for another month and we will check again. My question is - Have others had a delay before TMs come down?  I feel absolutely fantastic and have no SEs yet!!  My onc suggests scans next month if markers are still up, just to see if anything shows up.  If Femara doesn't work I have one more hormonal before my onc wants to go to chemo. I know I have been very lucky with my treatments and after 4 years I am still very healthy and happy but I am a bit down that maybe Femara which should be such a great treatment for me might not work. Hate visiting my onc and waiting for him to tell me what my own body is doing. Excuse me I'm just whining and need to get over myself. Thanks for taking the time to read. Moira Moiralf Dx 11/16/2007, IDC, 3cm, Stage IV, 9/13 nodes, mets, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Sep 2, 2012 07:27PM Moiralf wrote: Hi There Bulldogger, Great name by the way. I'm not going to be much help with all that you want to know but I wanted to get a reply to you. You and your mum have certainly had a hard time of it but here are a number of women whose cancer has been found in similar circumstances. There are things that can be done to help your mum. I know someone will come along who has had the compression fractures and can be more informative than I. Just hold on and they will be along soon. I'm thinking your mum must have been checked for mets elsewhere and if they are still only in her bones she has a reasonable chance of living many years yet. Being in as much pain as she is will make that seem unlikely but the pain can be better dealt with.(I've had bones mets for nearly 5 years and even with a couple of bumps on the road am still doing really well). Palliative care is not hospice. My hospice, and I live in New Zealand, deal with pain management the best, not my onc. When I had pain from hip mets and he wanted me to see them I panicked and thought it was the end. Not so at all. Pain was better managed until I had rads and that removed all pain. I was using two walking sticks to get around then and within a month I was walking again normally. I was 47 so found it hard to be like that but it was resolved I am on Femara too and it helping. The aredia will help her bones so it seems that they are giving her fairly standard treatment. But, pain is not ok and you need to push to have it bought under control. I know there are things that can be done for the compression, especially in the states. I have read about that on this site. Maybe if you search the site help you will find posts about it. You are doing great things for your mum and please know that there is still lots that can help. I wonder at not having herceptin but as I am HER2- I don't know too much about that. Others will be on their way soon to answer better that I can. This site is wonderful on many levels, not just for info but for friendship and an understanding of what everyone affected by this dratted illness goes though. Lots of humour pages too and they are so helpful to remember the lighter side of life. Sorry, for going on but I did want you to know that someone had heard and is willing to reach out and say Hi.  Moira

Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2012 02:40PM Moiralf wrote: Hi all, Thanks for that.  I had such a fast and strong response to Xeloda that I guess I thought Femara would be the same. I had scans done July and Oct and they were fine so hoping that continues. My onc scans quite a bit as I show few if any symptoms and my markers are a good general indicator that something is happening. i think I just need to relax and stop panicking that things are not changing fast enough. I'm often like this after a visit to my onc no matter what he says. I have had him for 4 years from the initial dx and yesterday was the first time he told me how well I'm doing and that I'm amazing in the way I have coped. Usually he is quite blunt and non committal. So that was nice to get some positives from him.  He must have had a wonderful relaxing Christmas. He is very hard-working and caring but not at all touchy feeling sort of man. So thanks for helping me get some perspective on this. This site and the beautiful women and men on it make such a difference in so many ways. Moira

Posts.Content: May 14, 2013 06:42PM Moiralf wrote: I totally agree with just about everything from the post above. We are in the stage 4 forum and that sucks. For us, if we stay on the boards we will face it time and again. There is little room for pretending. But we are all living right now and what I take from so many of those women who I miss so much, is their determination to LIVE. No one knows how short or long any life will be but those women knew that they needed to live fully. By their example, so do I. By their strength I find strength. Then I pay it forward. If not then what does happen to those new women(the ones    we were once).  When we did the count of stage 4 women, I noticed how many were lurkers, good on them, but if they had nothing to read and no one to offer the support they silently needed, what a terrible thing it would be. But, it hurts so bad right now. Time to wobble and then head up, smile on and live. Screw you cancer, you might win the end battle but you won't take my life. Moira

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2013 04:04PM Moiralf wrote: Oh Evans this is a heavy blow.  Not what you were wanting at all. It does take time to absorb the blow and then get up again and move forward. Plus you are mourning for your cousin, that is a big thing in it's own right.  Be gentle and kind to yourself and take each day as it comes. If you have anti-anxiety pills, now would be the time to use them.  There are more treatments out there and they just need to find the right one. Keep planning for your son's birthday if you can. Celebrate such an important time for you but if it is overwhelming get others to help pull it all together and rely on their support too. You have every right to feel heartbroken and sad so don't feel you have to be strong and brave all the time, take it one breath at a time and let yourself grieve for a little bit. Peace and blessings be with you. Moira
